functions: Provide assistance to women survivors of NRI/Overseas marriages.
Address deprivation of women's rights in NRI marriages.

dos: Verify groom’s marital, employment, financial, immigration, and other personal details.
Maintain regular communication with groom and family before marriage.
Ensure marriage registration in addition to religious ceremonies.
Keep in touch with family after marriage; monitor any reluctance or difficulty in communication.
Learn laws of the foreign country and rights available there against abuse.
Maintain emergency contact details and bank accounts.
Keep copies of important documents (passport, visa, marriage certificate, etc.) safely.
Be aware of Indian laws and legal safeguards.
Use Indian Embassy/Consulate assistance for complaints abroad and legal/financial aid.
donts: Do not make hasty decisions under pressure.
Do not treat marriage as a passage to migration or green card.
Do not finalize marriage without proper verification and in-person interaction.
Do not negotiate or trust matrimonial bureaus blindly.
Do not agree to marriage in secrecy or abroad without safeguards.
Do not remain silent in case of desertion, abuse, or cruelty.
Do not forge legal documents or participate in illegal acts.
Do not resort to violence or vigilantism against husband/in-laws.
Do not act vindictively; use proper legal channels for grievances.

Closure_Procedure_2010.Objective: Facilitate closure of complaints after receipt of Action Taken Reports (ATRs) through a simple and unambiguous procedure.

Format: Name of Official from whom ATR is Received

b. Heinous crimes (rape, gang rape, dowry death, acid attacks) – examine ATRs, may seek further status reports, must monitor till court presentation, communicate to complainant within 90 days
c. ATRs show allegations unsubstantiated or complaint frivolous/vague – closed under intimation to complainant

Issues related to civil disputes between the parties, such as contractual obligations
Issues related to division of property
Issues related to service matters
Issues related to labour/industrial disputes
Issues concerning civic issues and civic agencies
Matter sub judice before a Court/Tribunal (may be coordinated to facilitate justice)
Any matter pending before a State Commission or other statutory Commission
Matter already decided by the Commission
Matter outside the purview of the Commission
Matters where only financial help is sought for travel tickets or stay in foreign countries
Matters relating to visa requests/issuance, under jurisdiction of foreign Governments

3.Title: Receipt and registration of complaints
Steps: All complaints received by NRI Cell, entered in online complaint registration system with details of complainant, victim, respondent, date, file number etc.
Acknowledgement sent within 3 days for postal complaints; online complaints receive immediate email acknowledgement

4.Title: Processing the complaints
Steps: Complaints initially dealt with by Members; Chairperson may refer case to multiple members or Inquiry Committee
Complaint must disclose full picture; Commission may seek further information/affidavit
File created with note sheet of brief gist; emails/phone calls if details missing; file forwarded to Counsellor
Particulars may be sought from any person/authority; proceedings informed to complainant
Direct complaints to Chairperson/Members processed by NRI Cell
Matters not related to cross-country marriage transferred to appropriate section
If complaint not within mandate, recorded and sent to Deputy Secretary/Joint Secretary for closure
Complaints may be sent to legal officer for comments, opinion, recommendations

I.Title: Communications with Appropriate Authority
Police: Letter to police for ATR where investigation pending or failure to act; reply within 4 weeks
Police may be called in person to furnish information/report
Indian_Embassy_Abroad: Forward complaint to embassy when: both parties NRI residing abroad; Indian citizens residing abroad, aggrieved wife cannot travel; husband deserted wife and whereabouts unknown; other reasons deemed fit
Letters for appropriate action per law with Commission approval
Ministries: Communicate with Ministry of External Affairs, Ministry of Home Affairs, Ministry of Law & Justice to expedite summons/warrants/orders
Communicate with Indian Embassies & Overseas Indian Affairs division for legal/financial assistance to victim
Communicate with Passport authorities as needed
Communicate with employers of respondent through Indian Embassies abroad or other departments depending on nature of complaint

II.Title: Inquiry into Complaints
Preliminary_Consideration_Notice: If cognizance taken, issue notice to opposite party for information within 15 days with copy of complaint; signed by concerned Member/authorized officer
If reply not received, reissue notice
If still no reply, issue notices/summons as per Clause III
If acceptance refused, serve notice through Police
Reply sent to complainant for rejoinder
Notices_Summons: Summons issued to opposite party to appear and answer claims when complaint filed
Issued on failure to reply notices second time
Opposite party may appear in person or through authorized pleader
Summons accompanied by copy of complaint or concise statement
Failure to respond: serve summons through Police
Hearing_of_Complaint: Preliminary hearing with parties, Co-ordinator, Counsellor, expert member; proceedings recorded by counsellor
Ascertain if opposite party admits allegations
Complainant may file affidavit, produce list of witnesses/documents
Examine complainant witnesses; cross-examination by opposite party
Opposite party submits defense, list of documents/witnesses
If no further action: close complaint under intimation, send to Govt/authorities, or refer to State Police/Govt

III.Title: Inquiry Committee
III.Content: Commission may constitute Inquiry Committee under Section 8 NCW Act with Chairperson approval for urgent investigation or intervention

IV.Title: Powers relating to inquiries
Powers: All powers of civil court under Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
Summon and enforce attendance of witnesses, examine them
Requisition public records or copies from court/office
Issue commissions for examination of witnesses/documents
Require any person to furnish information relevant to inquiry, legally bound under IPC Sections 176 & 177
Forward case to Magistrate if offences under IPC Sections 175, 178, 179, 180 committed in view of Commission

V.Title: Steps after inquiry
Actions: Recommend prosecution/action against negligent public servant
Approach Supreme Court/High Court for directions/orders
Recommend immediate relief to victim or family
Provide copy of inquiry report to petitioner/representative
Send copy of inquiry report with recommendations to concerned Government/authority; comments/action taken within one month or extended period
Publish inquiry report with Government/authority comments and action taken/proposed

6.Title: Recording of Proceedings
Content: Note sheet reflects proceedings from receipt to final disposal
Orders, notices, summons, day-to-day proceedings recorded legibly
Order sheet signed by Member/authorized officer/committee and parties
Routine inter-office correspondence recorded separately in annexed file

7.Title: Mode of Communication
7.Content: All summons and notices sent by registered post/courier/email unless otherwise directed

8.Title: Procedure regarding Suo Motu Action
8.Content: Procedure applies mutatis mutandis to suo motu action taken by the Commission

act.title: The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956
act.preamble: An Act to provide in pursuance of the International Convention signed at New York on the 9th day of May, 1950, for the prevention of immoral traffic.
act.enactment: Be it enacted by Parliament in the Seventh Year of the Republic of India as follows:

sections.title: Short title, extent and commencement
content: This Act may be called The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act, 1956.
It extends to the whole of India.

This section shall come into force at once; and the remaining provisions of this Act shall come into force on such date as the Central Government may, by notification in the official Gazette, appoint.

sections.title: Definitions

content.a: “brothel” includes any house, room, conveyance or place, or any portion thereof, used for purposes of sexual exploitation or abuse for the gain of another person or for the mutual gain of two or more prostitutes.
content.aa: “child” means a person who has not completed the age of sixteen years.
content.b: “corrective institution” means an institution established or licensed under Section 21 where persons in need of correction may be detained, including shelters for under trials.
content.c: “magistrate” means a Magistrate specified in the Schedule as competent under the relevant section.
content.ca: “major” means a person who has completed the age of eighteen years.
content.cb: “minor” means a person who has completed the age of sixteen years but not completed eighteen years.
content.d: “prescribed” means prescribed by rules made under this Act.
content.f: “prostitution” means the sexual exploitation or abuse of persons for commercial purposes, and the expression “prostitute” shall be construed accordingly.
content.g: “protective home” means an institution established or licensed under Section 21 where persons needing care and protection may be kept, but does not include (i) a shelter for under trials or (ii) a corrective institution.
content.h: “public place” means any place intended for use by, or accessible to, the public and includes public conveyance.
content.i: “special police officer” means a police officer appointed by the State Government to be in charge of police duties under this Act in a specified area.
content.j: “trafficking police officer” means a police officer appointed by the Central Government under Section 13(4).

sections.comments: Prostitution—Police raid—Nine girls recovered—No evidence of brothel activity—Sexual intercourse by itself is not an offence—Prostitution by itself is not an offence. Case: Kumari Sangeeta v. State and another. 1996 Cr.R. 129 (Delhi)

sections.title: Rule of construction regarding enactments not extending to Jammu and Kashmir
content: Any reference in this Act to a law which is not in force in Jammu and Kashmir shall, in relation to that State, be construed as reference to the corresponding law, if any, in force in that State.

sections.title: Punishment for keeping a brothel or allowing premises to be used as a brothel
content: Any person who keeps, manages, or assists in the management of a brothel shall be punishable on first conviction with rigorous imprisonment of not less than one year and not more than three years, and with fine up to two thousand rupees.
For a second or subsequent conviction, the punishment shall be rigorous imprisonment of not less than two years and not more than five years, and with fine up to two thousand rupees.

sections.title: Punishment for keeping a brothel or allowing premises to be used as a brothel

clauses.a: Being the tenant, lessee, occupier or person in charge of any premises, uses, or knowingly allows any other person to use, such premises or any part thereof as a brothel.
clauses.b: Being the owner, lessor or landlord of any premises, or the agent thereof, lets the same with knowledge that it is intended to be used as a brothel, or is wilfully a party to such use.

presumptions: If a newspaper report states premises were found used for prostitution as a result of a search under this Act.
If a copy of the list of things found during the search is given to the person concerned.
sub_sections.note: Until contrary is proved, it is presumed the person knowingly allowed the premises to be used as a brothel.

sub_sections.content: On conviction under sub-section (2), any lease or agreement of the premises becomes void and inoperative from the date of conviction.

sections.title: Punishment for living on the earnings of prostitution

sub_sections.content: Any person over 18 years who knowingly lives, wholly or in part, on the earnings of prostitution of another person.

if_child_or_minor_involved.imprisonment: Not less than 7 years and up to 10 years

presumptions: Living with, or habitually in the company of, a prostitute.
Exercising control, direction or influence over the movements of a prostitute in a manner aiding, abetting or compelling prostitution.
Acting as a tout or pimp on behalf of a prostitute.
sub_sections.note: Until contrary is proved, such person is presumed to be knowingly living on prostitution earnings.

sections.title: Procuring, inducing or taking person for the sake of prostitution

clauses.a: Procures or attempts to procure a person, with or without consent, for prostitution.
clauses.b: Induces a person to go from any place, intending he/she may become an inmate of or frequent a brothel.
clauses.c: Takes or attempts to take a person, or causes a person to be taken, from one place to another for prostitution.
clauses.d: Causes or induces a person to carry on prostitution.

general.imprisonment: Not less than 3 years and up to 7 years (rigorous)

if_child_involved.imprisonment: Not less than 7 years, may extend to life

if_minor_involved.imprisonment: Not less than 7 years and up to 14 years

triability.a: Place from which a person is procured, induced, taken or attempt made.
triability.b: Place to which the person has gone as a result of inducement, or to which he/she is taken or attempt is made.

sections.title: Detaining a person in premises where prostitution is carried on

clauses.a: Detains any person in a brothel.
clauses.b: Detains any person in or upon premises with intent that such person may have sexual intercourse with someone other than their spouse.

general.note: Court may, for special reasons, impose a sentence of less than 7 years.

sub_sections.presumption: If a person is found with a child in a brothel, it shall be presumed (unless proved otherwise) that an offence under sub-section (1) is committed.

If a child or minor found in a brothel is medically detected to have been sexually abused, it shall be presumed (unless proved otherwise) that the child/minor has been detained for prostitution or sexually exploited for commercial purposes.

presumption_conditions: Withholds jewellery, apparel, money or property belonging to the detained person.
Threatens her with legal proceedings if she takes away such property lent/supplied to her.

sub_sections.protection: No legal action shall lie against the detained woman/girl by the person detaining her, for recovery of jewellery, apparel, property or money allegedly lent, supplied, or pledged.

sections.title: Prostitution in or in the vicinity of public place

sub_sections.offence: Any person carrying on prostitution, and the person with whom it is carried on, in premises within notified areas or within 200 meters of public religious worship, educational institution, hotel, hospital, nursing home or other notified public places.
If offence under sub-section (1) involves a child or minor.

general.imprisonment: Not less than 7 years; may extend to life or up to 10 years

punishment.note: Court may, for adequate and special reasons, impose a sentence less than 7 years.

clauses.a: Keeper of public place knowingly permits prostitutes to resort/remain for trade.
clauses.b: Tenant/occupier/person in charge knowingly permits use of premises for prostitution.
clauses.c: Owner/lessor/landlord or agent lets premises knowing it may be used for prostitution, or wilfully parties to such use.

if_hotel_involved.license: Suspension of hotel license for not less than 3 months and up to 1 year

explanation.hotel_definition: Same meaning as in clause (6) of Section 2 of the Hotel-Receipts Tax Act, 1980 (54 of 1980).

sub_sections.provision: State Government may, by notification, prohibit prostitution in specified areas considering population density, nature of persons frequenting, and other relevant factors.
Notification must clearly define the limits of the prohibited area.
Notification shall not take effect earlier than 90 days from issuance.

sections.title: Seducing or soliciting for purpose of prostitution

offences.description: By words, gestures, willful exposure, or otherwise tempts/attracts attention for prostitution.
Solicits, molests, loiters, or causes obstruction/annoyance to public for prostitution.

if_offender_is_male.imprisonment: Not less than 7 days; up to 3 months

sections.title: Seduction of a person in custody
sections.provision: Any person in custody, charge, care of, or in authority over another, who causes/aids/abets seduction for prostitution.

general.imprisonment: Not less than 7 years; up to life or 10 years

punishment.note: Court may, for adequate and special reasons, impose sentence of less than 7 years.

sections.title: Detention in a corrective institution

conditions: Female offender guilty of offence under Section 7 or 8.
Character, health, mental condition, and circumstances justify corrective detention.
sub_sections.order: Court may order detention in corrective institution instead of imprisonment, for 2–5 years.
proviso: Offender must be heard; court must consider offender's representation and probation officer’s report.
Court must record satisfaction that offender is likely to benefit from correction.

sub_sections.provision: Order of detention treated as sentence of imprisonment for appeals and limitation purposes.
State Government/authority may discharge offender after 6 months if likely to lead useful life; discharge may be conditional with licence.
Conditions may include residence requirements and supervision of activities.

sections.title: Notification of address of previously convicted offenders

sub_sections.provision: Court may order previously convicted offenders to notify residence/change of residence for up to 5 years after release.
Order becomes void if conviction is set aside on appeal.
Order may also be made by Appellate Court or High Court in revision.
Breaches of notification rules triable by Magistrate in district of last notified residence.

sections.title: Repealed/Removed
Special police officer and advisory body

sub_sections.provision: State Government shall appoint a special police officer for each specified area to deal with offences under the Act.
Special police officer shall not be below rank of Inspector.
District Magistrate may confer powers on retired police/military officers (Inspector or Commissioned Officer rank or above).

clauses.a: Special police officer shall be assisted by subordinate officers, including women police where possible.
clauses.b: State Government may associate an advisory body (max 5 social welfare workers, including women) to advise on Act implementation.

sections.title: Special police officer and advisory body

sub_sections.provision: The Central Government may appoint trafficking police officers for offences committed across more than one State. They have powers of special police officers with jurisdiction across India.

sections.title: Offences to be cognizable
sections.provision: All offences under this Act shall be cognizable under the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973.

proviso.i: Arrest without warrant may be made only by special police officer or under his direction/prior approval.
proviso.ii: When subordinate officer is directed to arrest, the special police officer must issue a written order specifying person and offence; officer must inform arrestee and show order if required.
proviso.iii: Police officer not below Sub-Inspector, specially authorised, may arrest without order if delay risks destruction of evidence, escape of offender, or false identity. Report must be made to special police officer as soon as possible.

sections.title: Search without warrant

sub_sections.provision: Special/trafficking police officer may enter and search premises without warrant if offence suspected and delay in obtaining warrant may cause harm, after recording reasons.
Before search, officer shall call two or more respectable inhabitants (at least one woman) of locality to witness search. Written order may be issued to them.
sub_sections.proviso: Woman witness need not be from same locality.

sub_sections.provision: Failure to attend and witness search without reasonable cause constitutes offence under Section 187 IPC.
Officer may remove all persons found in premises during search.
Removed persons must be produced before appropriate Magistrate immediately.
Produced person must be medically examined to determine age, detect injuries from sexual abuse, or presence of sexually transmitted diseases.
sub_sections.explanation: ‘Registered medical practitioner’ as defined in Indian Medical Council Act, 1956.

sub_sections.provision: Officer and witnesses are protected from civil/criminal liability for lawful acts during search.

Officer must be accompanied by at least two women police officers. Interrogation of woman/girl must be by woman officer, or in her absence, in presence of lady member of recognised welfare institution/organisation.
sub_sections.explanation: Recognised welfare institution/organisation means one recognised by State Government.

sections.title: Search without warrant

sub_sections.provision: Provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 apply to searches under this section as if made under authority of a warrant issued under Section 94 of that Code.

sections.title: Rescue of person

sub_sections.provision: If Magistrate believes a person is living in or forced into prostitution in a brothel, he may direct a police officer (not below Sub-Inspector) to enter, remove the person, and produce her before him.
Police officer must produce rescued person before the Magistrate immediately.

sections.title: Intermediate custody of persons removed or rescued

sub_sections.provision: If rescued person cannot be produced before the appropriate Magistrate, she must be produced before nearest Magistrate, who may order safe custody until produced before appropriate authority.
proviso: Custody shall not be given to a person with harmful influence.

sub_sections.provision: When produced before Magistrate, inquiry shall be made regarding correctness of information, age, character, antecedents, suitability of parents/guardians, and home environment. Magistrate may direct Probation Officer to investigate.
Magistrate may order safe custody during inquiry.
provisos: If rescued person is child/minor, Magistrate may place her in institution under Children Act.
Custody for this purpose cannot exceed 3 weeks.
Custody must not be with person having harmful influence.

sub_sections.provision: If inquiry confirms correctness of information and need of care/protection, Magistrate may order detention for 1–3 years in protective home or suitable custody, with reasons recorded.
sub_sections.proviso: Custody shall not be with religious body. Court may require bond with undertakings for care, education, medical/psychiatric treatment, and supervision, for up to 3 years.

sub_sections.provision: Magistrate may summon a panel of 5 respectable persons (3 women wherever practicable) to assist in inquiry, preferably social welfare workers.

If brothel exists within 200 metres of public place (per Section 7), Magistrate may issue notice to owner/landlord/tenant to show cause. After hearing, Magistrate may order eviction of occupier and restrict re-letting.
sub_sections.proviso: If owner/landlord/agent is innocent, premises may be restored with direction not to lease to offending person.

sub_sections.provision: Court convicting under Section 3 or 7 may pass eviction/closure orders without further notice.
Orders under sub-section (1) or (2) are final, not subject to appeal, and expire after 1 year or 3 years as applicable.
sub_sections.proviso: If conviction under Section 3 or 7 is overturned on appeal, closure order is also set aside.

sub_sections.provision: When closure order is passed, any lease/agreement in respect of premises becomes void.
If owner/landlord/agent fails to comply with directions, he is punishable with fine up to 500 rupees or deemed guilty of offence under Section 3(2)(b) or Section 7(2)(c).

sections.title: Application for being kept in a protective home or provided care and protection by court

sub_sections.provision: A person carrying on or being made to carry on prostitution may apply to Magistrate for an order to be kept in a protective home or provided care and protection by the court.
Pending inquiry, Magistrate may direct interim custody as deemed proper.
After inquiry (including through Probation Officer) and hearing the applicant, if satisfied, Magistrate may order:
options: Supervision by a person appointed by Magistrate for specified period

sections.title: Removal of prostitute from any place

sub_sections.provision: Magistrate, on receiving information that a person is a prostitute in his jurisdiction, may issue notice to appear and show cause why she should not be required to remove herself.
Notice must be accompanied by copy of record of information and served on the person.

Magistrate shall inquire into truth of information, allow evidence, and if satisfied, order the person to remove herself to specified place within specified time (not less than 7 days) and prohibit re-entry without written permission.
Penalties:
clauses: Failure to comply or re-enter without permission: fine up to 200 rupees, and for continuing offence, additional fine up to 20 rupees per day.
Harbouring or concealing such person knowing removal order is in force: same penalties.

sections.title: Protective homes

sub_sections.provision: State Government may establish and maintain protective homes and corrective institutions.
No one else may establish/maintain such institutions except under licence issued by State Government.
State Government may issue licence on application, subject to conditions. Preference to entrust management to women. Transitional provision allows existing homes to apply within 6 months.
Before issuing licence, State may require investigation by designated officer/authority.
Licence valid for specified period, renewable on application 30 days before expiry.
Licence is non-transferable.
State may revoke licence for breach of conditions, mismanagement, or violation of Act/rules, after giving opportunity to show cause.
On revocation, home or institution shall cease to function.
State Government may vary or amend licences.
State Government may transfer inmates between homes/institutions where desirable, with reasons recorded.
proviso: Transferred person cannot be detained longer than original period.

sub_sections.provision: Penalty: Establishing/maintaining home without licence — fine up to 1000 rupees for first offence; subsequent offences — imprisonment up to 1 year or fine up to 2000 rupees or both.

sections.title: Production of records
sections.provision: Licensed institutions must produce records/documents before court when required.

sections.title: Trials
sections.provision: Only a Metropolitan Magistrate or Judicial Magistrate of the first class may try offences under Sections 3–8.

sections.title: Power to establish special Courts

sub_sections.provision: State Government may establish special Courts of Judicial Magistrates (first class) or Metropolitan Magistrates for speedy trial of offences under this Act.
Unless directed otherwise by High Court, such Courts exercise jurisdiction only for cases under this Act.
Jurisdiction of special Court extends throughout district or metropolitan area.
Such Courts deemed to be established under CrPC Section 11(1) or 16(1); CrPC provisions apply.

sections.explanation: High Court means as defined in Section 2(e) of CrPC, 1973.

sections.title: Power of Central Government to establish special Courts

sub_sections.provision: Central Government may establish special Courts of Judicial Magistrates (first class) or Metropolitan Magistrates for trial of offences under this Act committed in more than one State.
Provisions of Section 22A apply mutatis mutandis to Courts established under this section.

sections.title: Power of court to try cases summarily
sections.provision: State Government may direct that offences under this Act shall be tried summarily by a Magistrate, including presiding officer of a special court under Section 22A.
details: Sections 262–265 CrPC apply to such trials.
Magistrate may pass imprisonment up to 1 year in summary trial.
If at commencement or during trial it appears imprisonment exceeding 1 year may be required, or case unsuitable for summary trial, Magistrate must record order and proceed with regular trial.

sections.title: Power to make rules

sub_sections.provision: State Government may make rules by notification in Official Gazette to carry out purposes of the Act.
Rules may provide for:
clauses: Notification of any place as public place
Custody and maintenance of persons under Section 17(1)
Discharge of offender under Section 10A(3) and form of licence
Detention/keeping of persons in protective or corrective institutions and their maintenance
Notification of address by released convicts under Section 11
Delegation of authority to appoint special police officer under Section 13(1)
Carrying into effect provisions of Section 18
Management of protective homes/corrective institutions (applications, licences, accounts, registers, care and discipline, transfers, inspections, etc.)

sub_sections.provision: Rules under clause (d) or (g) may provide penalty for breach, fine up to 250 rupees.
All rules made under this Act to be laid before State Legislature.

sections.title: Act not to be in derogation of certain other Acts
sections.provision: This Act does not derogate from the Reformatory Schools Act, 1897, or any State Act relating to juvenile offenders.

sections.title: Repeal and savings

sub_sections.provision: On commencement of this Act (except Section 1), all State Acts relating to suppression of immoral traffic or prevention of prostitution stand repealed.
Notwithstanding repeal, anything done, order made, or action taken under such State Acts remains valid, if not inconsistent, until superseded by action under this Act.

schemes.objective: Provides a cash incentive to pregnant and lactating women to improve their health and nutritional status.

ParliamentaryQuestion.Subject: Change of name of Coimbatore International Airport

Questions.Text: Whether the Union Government has received any proposal to change the name of Coimbatore International Airport and if so, the details thereof;
Whether the Government is likely to consider the proposal;
If so, the details thereof and if not, the reasons therefor?

Answer.Summary: Airports are generally named after the city where they are located unless a specific proposal is made by the State Government and approved through proper legislative and administrative processes. No proposal has been received from the Tamil Nadu Government to rename Coimbatore Airport.

Details.GeneralRule: Airports are known by the name of the city where they are located.
RenamingProcess: Proposal must be submitted by the respective State Government.
State Legislative Assembly must pass a Resolution supporting the renaming.
Consultation occurs with relevant Ministries and Departments at the Union level.
Proposal is then sent to the Union Cabinet for final approval.
Details.CurrentStatus: No proposal to rename Coimbatore Airport has been received from the State Government of Tamil Nadu.

consumer_protection_faq.question: When was the Consumer Protection Act 2019 enacted?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: The Consumer Protection Act 2019 was notified on August 9th, 2019, and came into effect on July 20th, 2020.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What are the main features of the Consumer Protection Act 2019?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: The Act includes provisions for e-commerce and direct selling, establishes the Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA), introduces strict norms for misleading advertisements and product liability, revises pecuniary jurisdiction, allows easier dispute resolution, defines unfair trade practices including unfair contracts, and provides for alternate dispute resolution through mediation.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Who is considered a consumer under the Act?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: A consumer is a person who buys goods or hires services for consideration, including offline or online purchases, teleshopping, direct selling, or multi-level marketing, and includes users with approval or beneficiaries of services.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Who is not considered a consumer?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Persons who obtain goods/services free of charge, buy for resale or commercial purposes, or avail services under a contract of service (except for self-employment use) are not considered consumers.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What are the consumer rights guaranteed under the Act?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: The six rights are: Right to Safety, Right to be Informed, Right to Choose, Right to be Heard, Right to Seek Redressal, and Right to Consumer Awareness.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What are goods under the Act?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Goods mean every kind of movable property and include food as defined under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Who can file a complaint?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: A complaint can be filed by a consumer, voluntary consumer association, Central/State Government, Central Authority, multiple consumers with the same interest, legal heirs of a deceased consumer, or parent/guardian of a minor consumer.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Can a person buying goods for business make a complaint?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: No, complaints cannot be filed for goods/services bought for business or commercial purposes.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What are Consumer Disputes Redressal Agencies?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: They are quasi-judicial bodies established at District, State, and National levels to provide simple, speedy, and inexpensive redressal to consumer grievances.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is the pecuniary jurisdiction of the Commissions?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: District Commission: up to 1 crore, State Commission: 1 crore to 10 crore, National Commission: above 10 crore.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Where can a complaint be filed?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: A complaint can be filed at the District Commission within whose jurisdiction the cause of action arose, or where the complainant or opposite party resides or carries business.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is meant by ‘deficiency’?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Deficiency is any fault, imperfection, shortcoming, or inadequacy in the quality, nature, or performance of goods/services, including negligence or omission causing loss or injury.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is an unfair contract?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: A contract with terms causing significant disadvantage to the consumer, such as excessive deposits, disproportionate penalties, unilateral termination rights, or unreasonable obligations.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is a misleading advertisement?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: An advertisement that falsely describes a product/service, gives false guarantees, conveys misleading representations, or deliberately conceals important information.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Who can be held liable for a misleading advertisement?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Manufacturers, advertising agencies, celebrity endorsers, and publishers can be held liable.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is e-commerce under the Act?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: E-commerce is buying or selling goods/services, including digital products, over digital or electronic networks.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is the Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA)?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: CCPA is a regulatory body to protect consumer rights, prevent unfair trade practices, investigate complaints suo motu or on complaint, and file cases before the commissions.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is product liability?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Product liability is the responsibility of manufacturers, sellers, or service providers to compensate consumers for harm caused by defective products or deficient services.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Who can be held liable in a product liability action?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: The manufacturer, service provider, or product seller (if they exercised control, modified the product, or provided independent express warranties).

consumer_protection_faq.question: What defences are available in product liability cases?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Defences include misuse, alteration, obvious danger, warnings/instructions provided, use under expert supervision, or consumer under influence of alcohol/drugs.

consumer_protection_faq.question: How can a complaint be filed?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Complaints can be filed in writing offline or online at http://edaakhil.nic.in/. They can be submitted in person, by agent, or by registered post with necessary copies.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Is mediation available?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Yes, mediation can be used with the consent of both parties at any stage of the complaint. There is no fee, and no appeal is allowed after settlement.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Is an advocate required to file a complaint?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: No, consumers can file and represent complaints themselves as the commissions follow informal procedures.

consumer_protection_faq.question: What is the time limit to file a complaint?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Within two years from the date the cause of action arose (deficiency in service or defect in goods).

consumer_protection_faq.question: What reliefs are provided by the Commissions?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Reliefs include removal/replacement of goods, refund, removal of service deficiencies, compensation, stopping unfair trade practices, withdrawal of hazardous goods, corrective advertisements, and costs to parties.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Can appeals be filed against Commission orders?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Yes, District to State Commission: 30 days, State to National: 30 days, National to Supreme Court: 45 days.

consumer_protection_faq.question: Is there a fee for filing complaints?
consumer_protection_faq.answer: Yes, fees depend on the value of goods/services and the Commission level. Appeals require 50% of the award amount as fee.
